awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Robert A. Jeffs is " Classifying Convex Neural Codes". The host institution for the fellowship is Carnegie Mellon University, and the sponsoring scientist is Florian Frick.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Fundamental progress in the study of convex neural codes:

  • Completely classified the possible combinations of open, closed, and non-degenerate embedding dimensions among codes.
  • Proved that recognizing (open or closed) convex codes in dimension 2 is algorithmically decidable (joint work with Boris Bukh).
  • Classified which codes can be realized by axis-parallel boxes (joint work with Miguel Benitez, Siran Chen, Tianhui Han, Kinapal Paguyo, and Kevin A. Zhou).
  • Described the first example of a 3-sparse code with closed embedding dimension 3, and open embedding dimension at least 4 (joint work with Henry Siegel, David Staudinger, and Yiqing Wang). 

Novel results in discrete geometry and related fields:

  • Proved novel bounds on Gromov-Hausdorff distances between spheres, verifying conjectured equality in infinitely many cases for the first time (joint work with Michael Harrison).
  • Proved that there are graphs that are not d-Tverberg is arbitrarily large dimensions (joint work with Florian Frick).
  • Proved sharp estimates for the number of d-representable and d-collapsible complexes on n vertices (joint work with Boris Bukh). 

Service and organizing activities:

  • Advised undergraduate teams in 8-week research projects in 2022 and 2023, through Summer Experiences in the Mathematical Sciences at Carnegie Mellon University.
  • Organized 2022-23 Algorithms, Combinatorics, and Optimization Seminar at Carnegie Mellon University.
  • Organized Minisymposium on Geometric CombinatoricsCanadian Discrete and Algorithmic Mathematics Conference (CanaDAM) in 2023.
  • Organized Special Session on Topological and Geometric Methods in Combinatorics at AMS Spring Central Sectional, University of Cincinnati in 2023. 

Last Modified: 09/20/2024
Modified by: Robert A Jeffs

por.por_txt_cntn:
Fundamental progress in the study of convex neural codes:

Completely classified the possible combinations of open, closed, and non-degenerate embedding dimensions among codes.
Proved that recognizing (open or closed) convex codes in dimension 2 is algorithmically decidable (joint work with Boris Bukh).
Classified which codes can be realized by axis-parallel boxes (joint work with Miguel Benitez, Siran Chen, Tianhui Han, Kinapal Paguyo, and Kevin A. Zhou).
Described the first example of a 3-sparse code with closed embedding dimension 3, and open embedding dimension at least 4 (joint work withHenry Siegel, David Staudinger, and Yiqing Wang).



Novel results in discrete geometry and related fields:

Proved novel bounds on Gromov-Hausdorff distances between spheres, verifying conjectured equality in infinitely many cases for the first time (joint work with Michael Harrison).
Proved that there are graphs that are not d-Tverberg is arbitrarily large dimensions (joint work with Florian Frick).
Proved sharp estimates for the number of d-representable and d-collapsible complexes on n vertices (joint work with Boris Bukh).



Service and organizing activities:

Advised undergraduate teams in 8-week research projects in 2022 and 2023, through Summer Experiences in the Mathematical Sciences at Carnegie Mellon University.
Organized 2022-23 Algorithms, Combinatorics, and Optimization Seminar at Carnegie Mellon University.
OrganizedMinisymposium on Geometric CombinatoricsCanadian Discrete and Algorithmic Mathematics Conference (CanaDAM) in 2023.
Organized Special Session on Topological and Geometric Methods in Combinatorics at AMS Spring Central Sectional, University of Cincinnati in 2023.
